materials.raw_text: Cobalt (Co) 12.5 g, Germanium (Ge) 15 g, Niobium (Nb) 11.5 g, Zirconium (Zr) 27 g

sourcing.instructions: Cobalt: Purchase from a reputable chemical supplier or online marketplace; Germanium: Available from electronics suppliers or chemical suppliers; Niobium: Obtain from metal suppliers or specialty chemical vendors; Zirconium: Acquire from metal distributors or online sources.
steps: Cobalt: Purchase from a reputable chemical supplier or online marketplace; Germanium: Available from electronics suppliers or chemical suppliers; Niobium: Obtain from metal suppliers or specialty chemical vendors; Zirconium: Acquire from metal distributors or online sources.

1. Measure out 12.5 g of Cobalt using an analytical balance. 2. Measure 15 g of Germanium. 3. Measure 11.5 g of Niobium. 4. Measure 27 g of Zirconium. 5. Combine all measured materials in a clean, dry mixing container. 6. Use a mechanical mixer to blend the powders uniformly for at least 10 minutes.
preparation.raw_text: 1. Measure out 12.5 g of Cobalt using an analytical balance. 2. Measure 15 g of Germanium. 3. Measure 11.5 g of Niobium. 4. Measure 27 g of Zirconium. 5. Combine all measured materials in a clean, dry mixing container. 6. Use a mechanical mixer to blend the powders uniformly for at least 10 minutes.

steps: 1. Transfer the mixed powders into a refractory crucible. 2. Preheat the furnace to 1000 °C. 3. Maintain the temperature for 2 hours, allowing the materials to fully react and fuse together.
heating.raw_text: 1. Transfer the mixed powders into a refractory crucible. 2. Preheat the furnace to 1000 °C. 3. Maintain the temperature for 2 hours, allowing the materials to fully react and fuse together.

steps: 1. Turn off the furnace and allow it to cool down naturally to room temperature (approximately 1-2 hours). 2. Do not open the furnace until it has cooled completely to avoid thermal shock.
cooling.raw_text: 1. Turn off the furnace and allow it to cool down naturally to room temperature (approximately 1-2 hours). 2. Do not open the furnace until it has cooled completely to avoid thermal shock.

steps: 1. Once cooled, remove the solid sample from the crucible. 2. Inspect for any irregularities or rough edges. 3. Sand the surface with 220-grit sandpaper to achieve a smooth finish. 4. Optionally, apply a sealing agent to protect the surface, if required.
